document.docTitle: Identity on Filchneria heteroptera (Wu, 1938) (Plecoptera: Perlodidae) with a new record of Paraleuctra cercia (Okamoto, 1922) from China

emphasis.docTitle:
Identity on
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
( Plecoptera : Perlodidae ) with a new record of
Paraleuctra cercia ( Okamoto, 1922 )
from China

subSection.paragraph: ZIXIANG TANG 1,4 , JIE WANG 2,5 , WEIHAI LI 1,6* & HAKAN BOZDOĞAN 3,7

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Henan International Joint Laboratory of Taxonomy and Systematic Evolution of Insecta, Xinxiang , Henan 453003, China
Department of Biological Center, Harbin Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Harbin 150086, China
Kırşehir Ahi Evran University, Vocational School of Technical Sciences, Department of Plant and Animal Production, 40100, Kırşehir , Turkey

subSection.paragraph:
7
�
hakan.bozdogan@ahievran.edu.tr ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-6836-4383

* Corresponding author.
� lwh7969@163.com

Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
is rediscovered from Heilongjiang Province of northeastern China . A supplementary description and illustrations including aedeagal structures based on newly collected specimens are provided.
Filchneria dongruihangi Chen, 2020
is considered here as a junior synonym of
F. heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
.
Paraleuctra cercia ( Okamoto, 1922 )
is reported from Liaoning and Heilongjiang provinces, China for the first time.

Key words: stonefly ,
Perlodidae
,
Filchneria
,
new synonym
,
Paraleuctra

The perlodid genus
Filchneria Klapálek, 1908
belongs to the
Perlodes
genus group ( Zwick 1997 ). It is a small Palearctic genus with 16 named species (DeWalt et al. 2023). Ten species had been recorded in China by
Huo et al . (2022)
before
F. tianshana Chen & Ma, 2022
was described and
F. kuenluensis
was transferred to
Perlodinella
by Teslenko & Palatov (2023) .

Recently, several species were redescribed or provided with supplementary descriptions by
Huo et al . (2022)
and Teslenko and Palatov (2021 , 2023 ). However, types of
F. heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
were lost during World War II and the War of Liberation in China ( Wu 1962 ) and have not been re-described in the recent studies mentioned above.

In spring 2023, we collected new material of
Filchneria
adults from the same locality on the Songhua River where
Filchneria sp.
( Chen 2019 ) was reported for the first time. The identity of our material was confirmed by comparing with
F. dongruihangi Chen, 2020
and
F. heteroptera
. The collection time of type specimen of
F. heteroptera
( paratype ♀ ) in the original records is dated mid-May (
18. V .1929
). The specimens examined by Chen (2020) were collected in late April ( 25.IV.2020 ), and our material was collected in late April to early May. Here, we present revised descriptions with digital micrographs of the adult male, including the fully extruded aedeagus and paraprocts of
F. heteroptera
, discuss morphological variability, and confirm that
F. dongruihangi
is a junior synonym of
F. heteroptera
. In addition, adults of
Paraleuctra cercia ( Okamoto, 1922 )
were collected during a trip to Harbin city, representing a new record species for Heilongjiang and Liaoning provinces, China .

The specimens are deposited in the Henan Institute of Science and Technology, Xinxiang Province, China ( HIST ) or the Entomological Museum of China Agricultural University ( CAU ). The figures were produced using a Leica S8APO microscope. Additional colour figures were created with an Imaging Source CCD mounted on a Leica M205 FA microscope and optimized with Adobe Photoshop. Two males collected by authors were everted in field by squeezing the abdomen during collection but one was not fully everted. In order to understand the consistence of the structure of aedeagus, abdomen of all males was removed and soaked in 10% KOH and then everted in laboratory. Terminology follows that of Zwick (1997) .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
. a: adult male from Alejin Island, dorsal view. b: adult female from Qunli Wetland Park, dorsal view (Photograph by Jie Wang).

Filchneria heteroptera (Wu, 1938), male from Qunli Wetland Park, a–d, aedeagus everted in field. a: ventral view. b: lateral view. c: another side, lateral view. d: caudal view. e: aedeagus with further eversion, dorsal view. f: aedeagus with further eversion, caudal view. Abbreviations: pd: posterodorsal lobe, al: anterolateral lobe, pl: posterolateral lobe.
figureCitation.captionText-4: FIGURE 5. Filchneria heteroptera (Wu, 1938), male from Alejin Island, everted aedeagus). a: dorsal view. b: ventral view. c: lateral view.d: caudal view.Abbreviations:ad: anterior dorsal lobe, pd: posterodorsal lobe, al: anterolateral lobe, pl:posterolateral lobe.
figureCitation.captionText-5: FIGURE 6. Filchneria heteroptera (Wu, 1938), female from Qunli Wetland Park. a–c: terminalia, with variations. d: published illustration of female terminalia by Wu (1938).

subSection.paragraph: Male ( Figs. 1a , 2–5 ). Body length 11.5–12.8 mm , forewing length 2.9–3.2 mm (n=3). Brachypterous, wings barely exceeding tergum 3; subhyaline; forewing with an irregular net at apex, anal area with 2–3 branches; hindwing with a smaller apical net, anal area larger with 3–8 branches ( Fig. 1a ; fig. 273 in Wu 1938 ; figs. 4A–B in Chen 2020 ). Abdominal segments dark brown ( Figs. 2a–b ). Terga 8–9 with paramedial light spots of similar shape and size, the shape of spot varied from subtriangular to kidney-shaped, the lateral and anterior margins of the spots resemble an “M” ( Figs. 2a, 2c ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, male from Alejin Island. a: male abdomen, dorsal view. b: male abdomen, ventral view. c: published illustration of male terminalia by Wu (1938) , dorsal view.

FIGURE 3 .
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, male from Qunli Wetland Park, paraproct sclerites and lobes everted in field. a: dorsal view. b: ventral view. c: lateral view. d: caudal view. e–f: published illustrations of male paraproct by Wu (1938) .

FIGURE 4 .
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, male from Qunli Wetland Park, a–d, aedeagus everted in field. a: ventral view. b: lateral view. c: another side, lateral view. d: caudal view. e: aedeagus with further eversion, dorsal view. f: aedeagus with further eversion, caudal view. Abbreviations: pd: posterodorsal lobe, al: anterolateral lobe, pl: posterolateral lobe.

FIGURE 5 .
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, male from Alejin Island, everted aedeagus). a: dorsal view. b: ventral view. c: lateral view. d: caudal view.Abbreviations: ad: anterior dorsal lobe, pd: posterodorsal lobe, al: anterolateral lobe, pl: posterolateral lobe.

subSection.paragraph: Female ( Figs 6 ). Body length 13.8–16.2 mm , forewing length 14.3–15.5 mm (n=8). Macropterous; both wings with a smaller irregular apical net; forewing with 3–4 anal branches; hindwing with 9–11 branches at anal area ( Fig. 1b ; fig. 274 in Wu 1938 ; figs. 4C–D in Chen 2020 ). Subgenital plate weakly to distinctly sclerotized, posterior margin variable in shape, from being nearly truncate to moderately bilobed with a shallow median notch ( Figs. 6a–c ), however, the sclerotized portion seemingly nearly parallel-sided, with an obscure or dark anteromedian line, in aged specimen, but not fully sclerotized as in fig. 278 in Wu (1938) ( Fig. 6d ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6 .
Filchneria heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, female from Qunli Wetland Park. a–c: terminalia, with variations. d: published illustration of female terminalia by Wu (1938) .

subSection.paragraph:
Examined material. China : 2 males and 7 females (including one pair in copulation), handpicking, Heilongjiang Province , Harbin City, Songhua River, Qunli Wetland Park, 120 m , N 45.7503 , E 126.5086 ,
2023. V .1
, leg. Jie Wang & Weihai Li. 1 male and 1 female , handpicking, same place, at Alejin Island, 2023.IV.26 , leg. Yitong Fu.

Remarks. These specimens were all collected at the type locality of
Filchneria sp.
Chen, 2019 and surely belong to this species. Chen (2020) noted the similarities between
Filchneria sp.
and
F. dongruihangi
, but at that time the aedeagal structure of
Filchneria sp.
was unknown. Our results indicate that they are conspecific:
F. dongruihangi
has the same everted paraproct lobe but less extruded (comparing Fig. 3 with figs. 6A, 7D–E in Chen 2020 ) and the aedeagal lobes are of the same shape (comparing Figs. 4–5 with fig. 8 in Chen) but the posterolateral lobe in
F. dongruihangi
is not fully everted. Three of the females have very similar subgenital plate to as in
F. dongruihangi
(see Figs. 6b–c vs. fig. 9C in Chen 2020 ). When compared with
F. heteroptera ( Wu, 1938 )
, our specimens have very similar tergal spinal patterns, paraproct sclerite and everted lobe, and female subgenital plate ( Figs. 2–3 , 6 ). Therefore,
F. dongruihangi Chen, 2020
is placed as a junior synonym of
F. heteroptera
.

Distribution . The species is distributed in Liaoning , Jilin , and Heilongjiang provinces in northeastern China and Gansu Province in northwestern China . It was recently commonly found along the Songhua River and its largest tributary, the Nenjiang River.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Examined material.
China : 15 males and 18 females ( HIST ), handpicking, Heilongjiang Province , Harbin City , Xianglushan ,
342 m
, N 45.34 ’27.16’’, E 127.31 ’56.81’’, 2022.
V .2, leg. Jie Wang & Weihai Li
;
1 male and 10 females ( CAU ), Liaoning Province , Kuandian County , 2007. malaise traps
.

Remarks.
Leuctra cercia
was originally described by Okamoto (1922) from Japan and subsequently transferred to
Paraleuctra Hanson, 1941
by Kawai (1976) . Later it was reported from Russia ( Zhiltzova 1976 ) and South Korea (
Kim et al. 1998
). Teslenko (2006) recorded this species from Jilin Province , China . Herein,
P. cercia
is formally reported as a new record species of Heilongjiang and Liaoning provinces, China .

Zwick (2010) noted aberrant females with a cone-shaped projection on the anterior of sternum 8 from The Republic of Korea and Russian Far East, but at that time no adult males had been collected with the Korean females and these females were putatively identified as
P. cercia
. All the present female specimens have such cone-shaped projection of sternum 8 and males are not readily morphologically distinguishable from
P. cercia .
Financial support was provided by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 31970402).
